pullRequest.body:
Adds a conversion `TypeFun.ofCurried : CurriedTypeFun.{u, v} n -> TypeFun.{u, v} n`,
where `CurriedTypeFun.{u,v} n` is a (def-eq) abbreviation for `Type u -> ... -> Type u -> Type v`, i.e., the type of *curried* functions taking `n` arguments of type `Type u` to return an element of `Type v`, and
`TypeFun.{u, v} n` is an abbreviation for `TypeVec.{u} n -> Type v`.

It is generally more idiomatic to define type functions with multiple arguments in the curried style, but in the QPF development we use the uncurried equivalent `TypeVec n -> Type _`. Thus, having a canonical conversion from curried functions to uncurried gives us a canonical way to ask if a curried type function, say `Sum` is a QPF (namely, "is there an instance of `MvQPF (TypeFun.ofCurried Sum)`").

---

This is code ported from  https://github.com/alexkeizer/QpfTypes, where this conversion is crucial in presenting a high-level interface, in terms of idiomatic, curried, type functions to users, while being built on QPFs (and thus, uncurried typefunctions) underneath.

There is also a conversion in the other direction, from uncurried to curried, which I've decided to PR later, to keep this PR smaller and hopefully easier to review.

- [x] depends on: #10818 (all changes to `Fin2.lean` are part of 10818, not the current PR)

### PR summary [f272613939](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/10823/commits/f27261393933a28e110aa9940c999a347968941f)

#### Import changes

No significant changes to the import graph

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ ofCurried`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh short <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh <optional_commit>
```
</details>
The dependency PR got merged, I merged master into this branch and fixed the linter errors, so this should now be ready for review!

> Is this not a special case of the HasUncurry machinery?
It's close, but not exactly.

A big difference is that `HasUncurry` will uncurry it into `Type x ... x Type -> Type`, rather than `TypeVec n -> Type`, and I do specifically need the latter to interface with QPF instances. Some solutions for this:
1) Make specialized `HasUncurry` instances for `Type -> ... -> Type -> Type`, to uncurry this into `TypeVec n -> Type`. A downside is that `TypeVec` forces all arguments into the same universe, so if we have `Type u -> Type v -> Type _`, then this will become `Type u x TypeVec.{v} 1 -> Type`. Not exactly elegant.
2) Introduce a new `HasTypeVecUncurry` class which has those specialized instances: that is not really better than what we have in this PR
3) Introduce a coercions from `Type x ... x Type` to `TypeVec`, and then compose HasUncurry with this coercion. I guess this could work? To make it prettier, I could introduce a new syntax that is specific to type functions, which bundles the uncurrying with the coercion.

Another big difference is that `HasUncurry` delegates the recursion to typeclass synthesis machinery, and thus only works for concrete arities, while the solution in the current PR works for arbitrary/dynamic arities. 

@YaelDillies for this reason I still prefer the implementation in this PR over `HasUncurry`.
However, I'll concede my current use-case does not need the arbitary arities (yet), so if you feel the extra maintenance burden is not worth it, I'm also happy to implement option (3) above.

That sounds like reasonable motivation. Could you please summarize your comment in the module doc of your new file/docstrings of your new defs AND cross-reference your new definitions from the docstrings/module doc for `HasUncurry` and friends?
Is this not a special case of the `HasUncurry` machinery?
Is this not a special case of the `HasUncurry` machinery?

```suggestion
This abbreviation should only be used to talk about such functions where `n` is arbitrary.
```

pullRequest.title: feat: convert curried type functions into uncurried type functions
